Less Equality in U.S.

Income inequality in the US is high and has been rising further in recent years. In 2013, the average income of the top 10% was 19 times higher than that of the bottom 10%, up from a ratio of 11 to 1 in the mid-1980s and 12.5 to 1 in the mid-1990s. This compares to an OECD average of 9.6 to 1 in 2013.

Between 2008 and 2013, real average household disposable income increased by 2.5%. Household income at the bottom 10% fell by 3.2%, while at the top 10% it increased 10.6%.
In the last three decades, low-income households have not benefited at all from income growth. After accounting for inflation, the average income of the bottom 10% in 2012 was 3.3% lower than in 1985, despite overall household income increasing by 24%.
While the average household income (corrected by purchasing power differences) in the US is about 14% higher than in Canada and about 25% higher than in Germany and France, the average income of the bottom 10% in the US is 42% lower than in Canada and about 50% lower than in France and Germany.
